hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?
Origami help keep the noise out?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Colder? Maybe. Hard to say.
I fly drones—FPV, after hours, near the old zones.
Recently, there have been more signals out there. Not all friendly.
Feels like more eyes, less freedom, even in the air.
City feels tight, that’s for sure.
I fly FPV drones, mostly in the empty industrial sectors.
Lately, it’s harder—more patrol drones, crowded channels.
Last session, I cut it short. Didn’t like the traffic.
It’s not just the weather—it’s something in the movement.
Yeah, colder. Not just the temperature, either.
My thing is freestyle FPV drone flying—old railyards, fringe data zones.
It usually lets me clear my head after shifts.
Now, with vanished folks coming back, even the airspace feels off.
Saw unauthorized drones tracing grid patterns last week.
That never used to happen before Halden died.
Feels colder, inside and out.
I spend my free time weaving FPV drones through industrial wreckage—good for forgetting the city.
Last week, I noticed BCI tracker bands running autonomous routines. Definitely not hobbyists.
Neighbors who disappeared years ago waved up at my goggles.
Flying isn’t as private anymore, but it’s the only time I feel in control.
Funny, even my hands shook dodging official patterns.
Hard to tell which side is actually watching now.
Definitely colder, though maybe we’re just noticing more.
I fly custom FPV drones—freestyle, long range. Started before I worked in wearables.
After the BCI glitch, hobby airspace turned busy—half rebels, half repurposed government trackers.
I recognize Council grid algorithms, even when camouflaged. Last weekend I stayed low to avoid jamming.
Some Invisibles flashed old analog signals at me from rooftops—almost like a code from before BCI days.
I keep my logs private now. I can wipe a drone’s trace if needed.
Used to feel like freedom. Now it’s more survival, threading between new signals.
We’re all improvising, hoping the system isn’t watching the same sky.
